title: Pass mark for NAPLAN despite online glitch
text:
The body in charge of national literacy and numeracy testing has given itself a pass mark for delivering NAPLAN this year despite the problems that plagued the move to online testing.

More than 670,000 students - about half the total cohort - took the tests in May using computers instead of pens and paper.

But many had to re-sit the tests after having trouble connecting or saving their work.

The whole system is now under review.

But the Australian Curriculum and Assessment Reporting Authority's annual report for 2018/19 says it achieved the measure of successfully delivering and reporting on the national tests "including delivery of NAPLAN Online in 2019".

ACARA chair Belinda Robinson, who was appointed in August 2018, noted of the move online: "As with all large technology-related projects, this has not been without its challenges."

"There is, however, no doubt that moving online will deliver greater precision of performance assessment and the true benefits of online assessment will be more fully realised once all schools are online," she writes in the report's foreword.

Chief executive David de Carvalho was more blunt in his assessment, saying the connectivity issues were "regrettable".
